solution_line_template: If the population is halving then at the end of the third year, the population must have been {final_population} people in the fourth year * {halving_factor} = <<{final_population}*{halving_factor}={population_end_year_3}>>{population_end_year_3} people.

In the second year, the population was {population_end_year_3} people in the third year * {halving_factor} = <<{population_end_year_3}*{halving_factor}={population_end_year_2}>>{population_end_year_2} people.

And in the first year, the population was {population_end_year_2} people in the third year * {halving_factor} = <<{population_end_year_2}*{halving_factor}={population_end_year_1}>>{population_end_year_1} people.

Additional people moved out in the first year, so accounting for these shows the population was {population_end_year_1} people + {original_moved_out} people who moved out = <<{population_end_year_1}+{original_moved_out}={population_before_original_move_out}>>{population_before_original_move_out} people.

Then removing the new people shows there were originally {population_before_original_move_out} people - {new_people_moved_in} new people = <<{population_before_original_move_out}-{new_people_moved_in}={original_population}>>{original_population} people.
